entry.title: :focus-visible in WebKit
entry.summary: This is a nice update from Manuel Rego Casasnovas. Igalia has this idea to sort of crowd-source important web platform features that need to get worked on (that‚Äôs the sort of work they do). They call it Open Prioritization. ‚Ä¶ The post :focus-visible in WebKit appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: SVG Favicons in Action
entry.summary: Ever heard of favicons made with SVG? If you are a regular reader of CSS-Tricks, you probably have. But does your website actually use one? The task is more non-trivial than you might think. As we will see in this ‚Ä¶ The post SVG Favicons in Action appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Making A Strong Case For Accessibility
entry.summary: Accessibility is often overlooked or bolted on to the end of a project. Let‚Äôs figure out how to implement and advocate for accessibility from the inception of a project to the release or handoff and beyond.

entry.title: Tools And Practices To Speed Up The Vue.js Development Process
entry.summary: Even though Vue.js claims to have an approachable minimalist framework that can be incrementally adaptable, it can be a little bit overwhelming when starting as a Vue.js newbie. In this article, we‚Äôre looking at ways to make writing Vue.js a breeze.

entry.title: A Look at Building with Astro
entry.summary: Astro is a brand new framework for building websites. To me, the big thing is that it allows you to build a site like you‚Äôre using a JavaScript framework (and you are), but the output is a zero-JavaScript static site. ‚Ä¶ The post A Look at Building with Astro appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: The Web‚Äôs Worst Default
entry.summary: There are a lot of great defaults when it comes to browsers and the web. Think about all the accessibility features that are baked into HTML so that you don‚Äôt have to do weird stuff, like this example from Manuel‚Ä¶ The post The Web‚Äôs Worst Default appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: An Introduction To Figma Interactive Components
entry.summary: Interactive Components in Figma allows designers to create a component with states (hover, active, clicked, focus) and make it interactive so that every copy of the component will inherit those same interactions by default. Let‚Äôs explore how it can reduce the time and effort needed to create interactions for your mock-ups.

entry.title: How To Choose A Headless CMS
entry.summary: There is an array of Headless CMSes out there. In this article, we delve into headless CMS features to satisfy your content editors, marketers and yourself as a developer. For the experience headless practitioner, this could be a checklist to see what‚Äôs new out there. For those starting out on their headless journey, this could be a guide on what to look for.

entry.title: Using HSL Colors In CSS
entry.summary: In this article, Ahmad Shadeed explains what HSL is, how to use it, and shares some of the useful use-cases and examples that you can use right away in your current projects.

In text, maybe you‚Äôd use it around slashes because you want to be sure the words are treated individually but not have any physical space around the slash:‚Ä¶ The post Zero-Width Space appeared first on CSS-Tricks. entry.title: Email Testing Flow As It Should Be
entry.summary: With so many tools and approaches, email still has quite a few pain points, both for developers and email marketers. Email is difficult because it has too many aspects to set and a few instances with no common rules to follow.

entry.title: It‚Äôs A (Front-End Testing) Trap! Six Common Testing Pitfalls And How To Solve Them
entry.summary: When writing front-end tests, you‚Äôll find a lot of pitfalls along the way. In sum, they can lead to lousy maintainability, slow execution time, and ‚Äî in the worst case ‚Äî tests you cannot trust. But it doesn‚Äôt have to be that way. In this article, I will talk about common mistakes developers make, at least in my experience, and, of course, how to avoid them. Testing doesn‚Äôt need to be painful, after all.

entry.title: How do you make a layout with pictures down one side of a page matched up with paragraphs on the other side?
entry.summary: I got this exact question in an email the other day, and I thought it would make a nice blog post because of how wonderfully satisfying this is to do in CSS these days. Plus we can sprinkle in polish ‚Ä¶ The post How do you make a layout with pictures down one side of a page matched up with paragraphs on the other side? appeared first on CSS-Tricks. entry.title: When a Click is Not Just a Click
entry.summary: The click event is quite simple and easy to use; you listen for the event and run code when the event is fired. It works on just about every HTML element there is, a core feature of the DOM API.‚Ä¶ The post When a Click is Not Just a Click appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Fixing a Bug in Low-Resolution Mode
entry.summary: I was working on a bug ticket the other day where it was reported that an icon was sitting low in a button. Just not aligned like it should be. I had to go on a little journey to figure ‚Ä¶ The post Fixing a Bug in Low-Resolution Mode appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: The State Of Web Workers In 2021
entry.summary: The web is single-threaded. This makes it increasingly hard to write smooth and responsive apps. Workers have a bad rep, but can be an important and useful tool in any web developer's toolbelt for these kinds of problems. Let‚Äôs get up to speed on Workers on the Web!

entry.title: The Many Shades Of July (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)
entry.summary: Let‚Äôs welcome July with some fresh desktop wallpapers. Designed by artists and designers from around the world, they are available with and without a calendar. Enjoy!

entry.title: System *Things
Working around the viewport-based fluid typography bug in Safari
entry.summary: Sara digs into a bug I happened to have mentioned back in 2012 where fluid type didn‚Äôt resize when the browser window resized. Back then, it affected Chrome 20 and Safari 6, but the bug still persists today in Safari ‚Ä¶ The post Working around the viewport-based fluid typography bug in Safari appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Positioning Overlay Content with CSS Grid
entry.summary: Not news to any web developer in 2021: CSS Grid is an incredibly powerful tool for creating complex, distinct two-dimensional modern web layouts. Recently, I have been experimenting with CSS Grid and alignment properties to create component layouts that ‚Ä¶ The post Positioning Overlay Content with CSS Grid appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Scaling Organizations Should Consider Building a Website Backed by a CRM Platform
entry.summary: To make some terminology clear here: CMS = Content Management System CRM = Customer Relationship Management Both are essentially database-backed systems for managing data. HubSpot is both, and much more. Where a CMS might be very focused on content and ‚Ä¶ The post Scaling Organizations Should Consider Building a Website Backed by a CRM Platform appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Creating Custom Emmet Snippets In VS Code
entry.summary: In this article, Manuel explains why Emmet is one of his favorite productivity tools for writing HTML and CSS, and how you can create custom Emmet snippets in Visual Studio Code to help you improve your front-end workflows even more.

entry.title: Custom Property Brain Twisters

entry.title: How to Cancel Pending API Requests to Show Correct Data
entry.summary: I recently had to create a widget in React that fetches data from multiple API endpoints. As the user clicks around, new data is fetched and marshalled into the UI. But it caused some problems. One problem quickly became evident: ‚Ä¶ The post How to Cancel Pending API Requests to Show Correct Data appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Creating A Multi-Author Blog With Next.js
entry.summary: This article explains how we can connect different types of content in a Next.js application. With this technique, we can add any kind of one-to-one, one-to-many, or even many-to-many relationship to our projects.

entry.title: How To Run A UX Audit For A Major EdTech Platform (Case Study)
entry.summary: This article is a case study of how a UX audit affects a UI. It explains how a famous educational platform can be analyzed edX against Jakob Nielsen‚Äôs usability guidelines. To get started, Mark Lankmiller shares all of the criteria and metrics he used for his UX audit.

entry.title: Chapter 9: Community
entry.summary: In April of 2009, Yahoo! shut down GeoCities. Practically overnight, the once beloved service had its signup page replaced with a vague message announcing its closure. We have decided to discontinue the process of allowing new customers to sign up ‚Ä¶ The post Chapter 9: Community appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: The Rise Of Design Thinking As A Problem Solving Strategy
entry.summary: In the dynamic and unpredictable environments in which we work, even the most carefully crafted solutions can have a short shelf life. When we accept that our work is impermanent and our problem-solving abilities are limited, our goal can shift from delivering full solutions to developing tools that empower our users to adaptively design for themselves.

entry.title: TablesNG ‚Äî Improvements to table rendering in Chromium
entry.summary: When I blogged ‚ÄúMaking Tables With Sticky Header and Footers Got a Bit¬†Easier‚Äù recently, I mentioned that the ‚Äústickiness‚Äù improvement was just one of the features that got better for <table>s in Chrome as part of the TablesNG upgrade‚Ä¶ The post TablesNG ‚Äî Improvements to table rendering in Chromium appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Using Performant Next-Gen Images in CSS with image-set
entry.summary: The CSS image-set() function has been supported in Chromium-based browsers since 2012 and in Safari since version 6. Support recently landed in Firefox 88. Let‚Äôs dive in and see what we can and can‚Äôt do today with image-set().‚Ä¶ The post Using Performant Next-Gen Images in CSS with image-set appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: ‚ÄúWeak declaration‚Äù
entry.summary: PPK looks at aspect-ratio, a CSS property for layout that, for the most part, does exactly what you would think it does. It‚Äôs getting more interesting as it‚Äôs behind a flag in Firefox and Safari now, so we‚Äôll have ‚Ä¶ The post ‚ÄúWeak declaration‚Äù appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Smashing Online Workshops (July-October 2021)
entry.summary: Frontend and design are remarkably complex these days. That‚Äôs why we invite kind, smart folks from the community to run [online workshops](https://smashingconf.com/online-workshops/) for all of us to learn together. And we have new ones coming up, and we‚Äôd like to kindly welcome you to join in.

entry.title: Automating Screen Reader Testing On macOS Using Auto VO
entry.summary: Automated testing is an important part of any software project, including testing for accessibility. There are already tools for linting and integration testing accessibility, but what about end-to-end testing with real assistive technology? Since I hadn‚Äôt seen this before, I set out to build Auto VO, a driver for the VoiceOver screen reader.

entry.title: v1.11.0
entry.summary:
Added: support an experimental template for YouTube feed üì∫ Demo | Source
Aggregate content from any YouTube channel rss url https://www.youtube.com/feeds/videos.xml?channel_id=<replace_with_channel_id> Videos are embedded via iframe and loading accelerated by youtube-lite-embed Ads are reduced thanks to YouTube's policy for embedded videos üôÉ Works on mobile devices with butter smooth horizontal scroll. Caveat: the template works only with YouTube content. You cannot mix textual RSS feed or other video sources such as Vimeo. Changed: Default HTML template meta tag adjusted to match convention Changed: sources in template data is now ordered by last update timestamp (as opposed to alphabetical) Thank you @PiyushLosalka

entry.title: inherit, initial, unset, revert
entry.summary: There are four keywords that are valid values for any CSS property (see the title). Of those, day to day, I‚Äôd say I see the inherit used the most. Perhaps because it‚Äôs been around the longest (I think?) but also ‚Ä¶ The post inherit, initial, unset, revert appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Using Custom Elements in Svelte
entry.summary: Svelte fully supports custom elements (e.g. <my-component>) without any custom configuration or wrapper components and has a perfect score on Custom Elements Everywhere. However, there are still a few quirks you need to watch out for, especially around ‚Ä¶ The post Using Custom Elements in Svelte appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: If we‚Äôre gonna criticize utility-class frameworks, let‚Äôs be fair about it
entry.summary: I‚Äôm not here to raise a shield protecting CSS utility frameworks. I don‚Äôt even particularly like the approach, myself, and nothing is above fair criticism. But fair is a key word there. I can‚Äôt tell you how many times I‚Äôve ‚Ä¶ The post If we‚Äôre gonna criticize utility-class frameworks, let‚Äôs be fair about it appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Designing With Code: A Modern Approach To Design (Development Challenges)
entry.summary: After years of innovation in both tools and processes, the struggle between design and development is still real. This article focuses on the best practices for improving the design to development processes and how cutting-edge solutions, such as UXPin powered by Merge technology, can help in facilitating the change.

entry.title: Are we in a new era of web design? What do we call it?
entry.summary: Una is calling it the new responsive. A nod to the era we were most certainly in, the era of responsive design. Where responsive design was fluid grids, flexible media, and media queries, the new responsive is those things ‚Ä¶ The post Are we in a new era of web design? What do we call it? appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How to Create CSS Charts With Interesting Shapes, Glyphs and Emoji
entry.summary: Let‚Äôs forego the usual circles and bars we typically see used in charts for more eccentric shapes. With online presentations more and more common today, a quick way to spruce up your web slides and make them stand out is ‚Ä¶ The post How to Create CSS Charts With Interesting Shapes, Glyphs and Emoji appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Image To Text Conversion With React And Tesseract.js (OCR)
entry.summary: Do you have to process data manually because it is served through images or scanned documents? An image-to-text conversion makes it possible to extract text from images to automate the processing of texts on images, videos, and scanned documents. In this article, we look at how to convert an image to text with React and Tesseract.js(OCR), preprocess images, and deal with the limitations of Tesseract (OCR).

Ë¥æÊòéÂ≠êÔºåÂåñÂ≠¶Â∑•Á®ãÔºåÁéªÂ∞îÂÖπÊõºÈó®‰∏ãËµ∞Áãó ÈòÖËØªÂéüÊñá
‚ÄúLudwig Boltzmann, who spent much of his life studying statistical mechanics, died in 1906 by his own hand. Paul Ehrenfest, carrying on the work, died similarly in 1933. Now it is our turn to study statistical mechanics. Perhaps it will be wise to approach the subject cautiously. ‚Äù‚ÄúÁ©∑ÂÖ∂‰∏ÄÁîüÈíªÁ†îÁªüËÆ°ÂäõÂ≠¶ÁöÑÁéªÂ∞îÂÖπÊõºÔºå‰∫é 1906 Âπ¥‰∫≤ÊâãÁªìÊùü‰∫ÜËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÁîüÂëΩ„ÄÇËâæ‰º¶Ë¥πÊñØÁâπÔºàÁªßÊâø‰∫Ü‰ªñÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºå‰∫é 1933 Âπ¥ÂêåÊ†∑Ê≠•ÂÖ∂ÂêéÂ∞ò„ÄÇÁé∞Âú®ÔºåÁªüËÆ°ÂäõÂ≠¶ËøôÂùóÈòµÂú∞ËΩÆÂà∞Êàë‰ª¨È°∂‰∏äÂéª‰∫Ü„ÄÇÂú®ËøõÂÖ•Ëøô‰∏™È¢ÜÂüü‰πãÂâçÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂèØËÉΩÈúÄË¶Å‰∏âÊÄùËÄåÂêéË°å„ÄÇ‚Äù Ëøô‰∏ÄÊÆµÁúã‰∏äÂéªÂæàÂæàÊÇ≤Â£ÆÁöÑËØùÔºåÊòØËëóÂêçÁöÑÁâ©ÁêÜÂ≠¶ÂÆ∂ David Goodstein ËØ¥ÁöÑÔºåÂÆÉÂåÖÊã¨‰∫ÜÁªüËÆ°ÂäõÂ≠¶‰∏≠‰∏§‰∏™Êù∞Âá∫‰∫∫Áâ©ÔºåÁéªÂ∞îÂÖπÊõºÂíåËâæ‰º¶Ë¥πÊñØÁâπÁöÑÊÇ≤ÂâßÊïÖ‰∫ã„ÄÇËøô‰∏§‰∏™‰∫∫ÈÉΩÊòØÂΩìÊó∂ÁªüËÆ°ÂäõÂ≠¶È¢ÜÂüü‰∏≠ÁöÑÂ§ß‰Ω¨ÔºåÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏çÂêåÁ®ãÂ∫¶ÁöÑÊäëÈÉÅÁóáÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÈÉΩ‰ø°Â•âÂΩìÊó∂‰∏çÊòØ‰∏ªÊµÅÁöÑÊÄùÊÉ≥ÔºåÊúÄÂêé‰∏§‰∫∫ÈÉΩÊ≠ª‰∫éËá™ÊùÄ„ÄÇÂπ∂‰∏îÔºåÂêéËÄÖÊòØÂâçËÄÖÁöÑÂ≠¶Áîü„ÄÇ ÁéªÂ∞îÂÖπÊõºÁªàË∫´‰ø°Â•âÂéüÂ≠êÔºåÂú®Áé∞Âú®ÁúãÊù•ÁêÜÊâÄÂΩìÁÑ∂Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØÂú®ÈÇ£‰∏™Êó∂‰ª£Âç¥‰∏çË¢´‰∏ªÊµÅÊâÄÊé•Âèó„ÄÇÁéªÂ∞îÂÖπÊõºËØïÂõæÁî®ÂàÜÂ≠êËøêÂä®ËÆ∫Êé®Âá∫ÂÖ®ÈÉ®ÁöÑÁÉ≠ÂäõÂ≠¶ÁêÜËÆ∫ÔºåÊääÁÉ≠ÂäõÂ≠¶ÂΩíÁªì‰∏∫Âä®ÂäõÂ≠¶ÁöÑÁªüËÆ°ÁªìÊûúÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îËØïÂõæ‰ªéÂÆåÂÖ®ÂèØÈÄÜÁöÑÂä®ÂäõÂ≠¶ÁêÜËÆ∫‰∏≠ÊâæÂà∞‰∏çÂèØÈÄÜÁöÑÊ†πÊ∫ê„ÄÇ‰∏∫Ê≠§‰ªñÂíåÂîØÂÉèÁÉ≠ÂäõÂ≠¶ÁöÑÂá†‰∏™Â§ß‰Ω¨‰∫âËÆ∫‰∏ç‰ºë„ÄÇÂΩìÊó∂ÂàÜÂ≠êÂíåÂéüÂ≠êÂπ∂Ê≤°ÊúâÁõ¥Êé•ÁöÑÂÆûËØÅËØÅÊçÆËØÅÊòéÂ≠òÂú®ÔºåÂõ†ËÄåÂÖ∂ÂÆû‰∏çËÉΩÊÄ™È©¨Ëµ´ÂíåÂ••ÊñØÁâπÁì¶Â∞îÂæ∑‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÊûÅÂäõÂèçÂØπÔºå‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂùöÂÆöÁöÑÂÆûËØÅ‰∏ª‰πâËÄÖÔºå‰ªñ‰ª¨ÊãíÁªùÊé•Âèó‚ÄúÂéüÂ≠ê‚ÄùËøô‰∏™Â∞öÊú™Ë¢´ÂÆûËØÅÁöÑÊ¶ÇÂøµ„ÄÇÁéªÂ∞îÂÖπÊõº‰∏ÄÁõ¥Â§ÑÂú®‰∏ÄÁßçÂ≠§ÂÜõÂ•ãÊàòÁöÑÂ¢ÉÂÜµ„ÄÇÂΩìÊó∂ÁöÑËëóÂêçÁâ©ÁêÜÂ≠¶ÊúØ‰ºöËÆÆÁîöËá≥ÈÉΩ‰∏çÂéªÈÇÄËØ∑‰ªñÂèÇÂä†ÔºåÂ∞±Â•ΩÂÉè‰Ω†ÊåñÁ©∫‚Ä¶

entry.title: Using the `outline` Property as a Collapsable Border
entry.summary: The outline property in CSS draws a line around the outside of an element. This is quite similar to the border property, the main exception being that outline isn‚Äôt a part of the box model. It is often used for ‚Ä¶ The post Using the `outline` Property as a Collapsable Border appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: An Alternative Voice UI To Voice Assistants
entry.summary: Voice assistants are currently the most popular use case for voice user interfaces. However, due to the bad feedback loop resulting from voice assistants can only solve simple user tasks such as setting an alarm or playing music. In order for voice user interfaces to really break through, feedback to the user must be visual, not auditive.

entry.title: Links on Typography
entry.summary: I studied the fonts of the top 1000 websites. Here‚Äôs what I learned. ‚Äî Michael Li brings the data. San-serif has total dominance. ‚Äú[‚Ä¶] it is rare to go below 10px or above 24px.‚Äù And poor <h5> always being the ‚Ä¶ The post Links on Typography appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Client-Side Routing In Next.js
entry.summary: Next.js has a file-based routing system in which each page automatically becomes a route based on its file name. This article will guide you through almost everything you need to know about Routing in Next.js and point you in the direction of related topics and concepts.

entry.title: Perfect Tooltips With CSS Clipping and Masking
entry.summary: Clipping and masking have been around for a while now in CSS and even have pretty decent browser support. I recently worked on a project that needed to use a clipping technique for tooltips showing above links in text. Those ‚Ä¶ The post Perfect Tooltips With CSS Clipping and Masking appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Start Serving Optimized Images in Vue
entry.summary: Images have become extremely important to the effectiveness of websites. They speak a 1000 words, attract attention, and stimulate emotions. However, web performance is also a growing problem for most websites. And images are at the heart of many web ‚Ä¶ The post Start Serving Optimized Images in Vue appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Your Image Is Probably Not Decorative
entry.summary: Image placement on the modern web is highly intentional, helping to communicate the overall purpose of a page or view. This means that nearly every image you declare needs to have an alternate description.

entry.title: Inline Styles as Classes (lol)
entry.summary:
If you‚Äôre abhorred by using inline styles, just move that style to the class attribute! And then make sure you have CSS in place that, ya know, does what it says on the box. I've revolutionized CSS. pic.twitter.com/1AWCldyCwP ‚Äî Sam

entry.title: A Complete Guide To Accessibility Tooling
entry.summary: In a new short series of posts, we highlight some of the useful tools and techniques for developers and designers. Recently we‚Äôve covered HTML Emails and SVG Generators. This time we look into different kinds of tools to help you streamline your accessibility testing process. Don‚Äôt miss the next one.

entry.title: When CSS Isn‚Äôt Enough: JavaScript Requirements For Accessible Components
entry.summary: Spoiler alert: tooltips, modals, tabs, carousels, and dropdown menus are some of the user interface components that require more than CSS. To ensure accessibility of your interface, JavaScript is a necessary addition to accomplish focus management, respond to keyboard events, and toggle ARIA attributes.

entry.title: Web Design Done Well: Making Use Of Audio
entry.summary: Design often revolves around visuals, but the other senses deserve love too. In this article, we tune in to audio features that are making sites sing.
